author: cf0009
content: Eth 2 validators are known beforehard. Couldn't someone see who's gonna be the validator over the next blocks and keep ddos-ing the current validator bringing the network to a halt?

author: protolambda
content: Yes, if validator privacy was completely broken, and attackers had enough look-ahead.

author: protolambda
content: The protocol separates network identity and validator identity, but correlation/analysis can still be a problem.

author: cf0009
content: Is there some more info about this?

author: protolambda
content: The specs itself? Not sure what specifically you're looking for

author: cf0009
content: This could be a very low skill attack, and validators with low hardware spec that run from home could be screwed

author: protolambda
content: The ddos or the validator-deanonymization part of the attack? Clients implement a lot against the former, p2p is a completely untrusted layer. But yes, if you have a lot of resources, a "dumb" attack may still work. Validator privacy is the main line of defense for smaller stakers. More sophisticated staking setups could try publish through more than 1 p2p endpoint, but this isn't very standard (although things like Vouch support this, afaik).

author: cf0009
content: Both. By ddos I mean just renting some botnet. I'm not sure how the identity of a validator is protected, but possibly collecting info over time would do it

author: jgm
content: You may want to start by looking at how to map the identity of a validator to a specific IP address.  It's not particularly simple in the p2p network

author: potuz
content: I think it's sufficiently hard to gather enough info of enough validators purely from the p2p stack that it would be easier to hack into beaconcha.in and monitor requests to their site since they claim they don't even store IPs in their dbase.

author: cf0009
content: Thank you! This was an interesting read and it's much harder than I thought. Especially in a live, constantly changing network with 160k+ peers

author: protolambda
content: We're not at a 160k peers currently

author: protolambda
content: But yea, if it's around eth1 mainnet node count, it's not so easy

author: potuz
content: One of the byproducts that came out when beaconcha.in coded their 'streak' was that it was pretty easy to infer with a reasonable chance that several validators were being run on the same beacon with only this indicator. So at least for bigger stakers it is probably possible to identify their beacons. Presumably they are not signing on the same computer though and probably have several beacons for the same signer

author: ajsutton
content:
Yeah tends to be load balancers in place so if you manage to overwhelm one beacon node you'll just find their attestations suddenly start popping out somewhere else.  Does suggest it would be good practice to generally funnel most attestations through a subset of nodes to ensure you always have some previously unknown nodes to suddenly appear in.

And then depending on your risk tolerance you can start talking about multi-zone/multi-cloud type redundancy.  Basically standard operating procedure for keeping a website up at that point.
